msItem.title: Inscription relating to the bag's contents
msItem.note:
The inscription reads:
Particule compoti Henrici Fylongley nuper vicecomitis comitatus Warr' et Leyc', videlicet, de auxilio vicecomitis, finibus, amerciamentis, exitis et proficiis comitatum predictorum a festo Sancti Michaelis anno xxxvimo Regis nunc Henrici Sexti, usque idem festum tunc proximum sequentem, scilicet per unum annum integrum ut infra
Warr'
Leyc'

The bag was used as a container for a compotus roll belonging to Henry Fillongley/Fylongley, in his capacity as Sheriff of Warwickshire and Leicestershire, concerning the fines, amercements, exits and profits of those counties, from Michaelmas 36 Henry VI (29 September 1457) until the same feast-day the following year. The roll itself is not known to survive.

extent.seg: A bag made of undyed doeskin. It is bell-shaped in outline, with the mouth narrower than the base. Round the mouth of the bag is a double drawstring also made of doeskin. The two upper corner of the bag are finished with ornamental knots, the lower ones with tassles constructed of bunches of small strips of skin.

supportDesc.condition: The bag is in very good condition. The drawstrings on the bag are likewise in very good working order, apart from two damaged loops.

handNote.p: Written in a large, clear secretary script by a single hand. The text is now faded, and without ornament.

physDesc.accMat: A (not wholly accurate) diplomatic and an expanded transcription, and translation, by the Cambridgeshire antiquary Palmer, W. M. (William Mortlock), 1866-William Mortlock Palmer (1866-1939) survives inside the bag and has been digitised. The inscriptions in pencil on the front and rear are by the hand of H.L. Pink Pink, H. L..

origin.origDate: Presumably made in 1457, contemporaneously with the roll it was intended to carry.

provenance.p: Fillongley/Fylongley, Henry (fl. c. 1440-1460)Henry Fillongley/Fylongley (fl. c. 1440-1450): courtier, sheriff and between 1453 and 1457 Keeper of the Great Wardrobe of Henry VI. At some point during the 1440s, Fillongley was in possession of the Dunmows manor house, which stood on a rectangular moated site at Hall Orchard, on the outskirts of Fulbourn, near Cambridge. The earthworks for the moat survive, but the house was demolished in the 18th century. See A.F. Wareham and A.P.M. Wright, A history of the County of Cambridge and the Isle of Ely, Victoria County History (2022), vol. 10: Cheveley, Flendish, Staine and Staploe Hundreds (North-Eastern Cambridgeshire) and Aileen Connor, 'Investigations on a Medieval Moated Site at Hall Orchard, Fulbourn: An Archaeological Training Dig' (Fulbourn: Archaeological Field Unit, Cambridgeshire County Council, 2006), p. 6.

acquisition.p: Presented to Cambridge University Library by Miss C.E. ParsonsParsons, C.E., Little Abington, Cambs., in December 1949.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on an unpublished description of the manuscript composed in 2011 by Jayne Ringrose, with revisions by James Freeman in 2023.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

change.persName: James Freeman, Medieval Manuscripts Specialist, Cambridge University Library
